metadata.case_name: Appellants (Members of Hindu Undivided Family) v. Respondents

facts.text: The appellants are members of a Hindu undivided family of which the first appellant is the Karta.
Prior to August 21, 1956, the family owned 64.35 standard acres of land in village Kurali, District Patiala. The land stood in the revenue records in the name of the first appellant.
On December 23, 1957, the first appellant transferred 26 standard acres to one Babu Singh by a registered deed.
According to appellants, they had planted an orchard in 10 acres of land.

Appellants' contention was that the said 26 standard acres and the said 10 standard acres could not be taken into account while ascertaining surplus land under the Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, XIII of 1955.
Both claims rejected by the authorities.
By order dated January 20, 1961, respondent No. 3 declared 34.35 standard acres out of the said 64.35 standard acres as surplus land.
Appeal filed by the appellants against the said order was rejected.
Appellants filed a revision application before respondent No. 1.
While revision pending, appellants filed a writ petition in the High Court.
During pendency of writ petition, Punjab Legislature passed Amendment Act, XVI of 1962 inserting S. 32-KK in the principal Act.

Learned Single Judge held: 1) finding that appellants had not planted the said orchard within the statutory period was one of fact and could not be challenged in writ; 2) transfer of 26 standard acres hit by S. 32-FF and rightly ignored.
Main contention before High Court: each of the three appellants constituting the family entitled to retain 30 standard acres; total holding 64.35 standard acres, no surplus land.
High Court following Bhagat v. State of Punjab dismissed writ petition.
Letters Patent Appeal against High Court judgment dismissed in limine.
Present appeal by certificate against dismissal of writ petition.

legal_issues.text: Whether S. 32-KK of Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act is violative of Arts. 19(1)(f), 31, 14, 15(1) and not protected by Art. 31A.
Whether S. 32-KK infringes Art. 15(1) by discriminating against Hindu undivided families on ground of religion.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under Hindu Law every coparcener in Hindu undivided family acquires right in property on birth, entitled to joint possession; S.32-KK deprives descendants of rights, vests in Karta alone, infringes Art.19(1)(f) and discriminates under Art.14.
Effect of S.32-KK: head gets 30 acres, not each descendant, violative of Art.31.
S.32-KK applicable only to Hindu undivided families, discriminates on religion vs. other undivided families in Punjab, infringes Art.15(1).
S.32-KK not legislation for agrarian reform, not protected by Art.31A.
Each of three appellants entitled to 30 standard acres, total 64.35 <90, no surplus.

respondent_arguments.text: Orchard not planted within statutory period (finding of fact).
Transfer of 26 acres hit by S.32-FF, ignored for surplus.

court_reasoning.text: S.32-KK creates fiction: land of Hindu undivided family deemed land of landowner (Karta), no descendant entitled to claim as separate landowner; limited to purposes of Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Directly adverse to descendants' rights, prima facie infringes Arts.19(1)(f),31 but protected if within Art.31A.

court_reasoning.text: Art.31A protects laws for acquisition of estate/rights for agrarian reform; Act including ceiling provisions part of agrarian reform (citing Ranjit Singh).
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.32-KK equates family to individual unit for ceiling, prevents retaining >30 acres aggregate, part of surplus distribution scheme.

court_reasoning.text: Objects of Act: tenant rights, proprietary acquisition by tenants, ceiling 30 acres, acquire surplus for distribution; S.32-KK corollary to ignore post-1956 transfers (S.32-FF upheld in Pritam Singh).
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.32-KK deals with estate, concerned with agrarian reform, protected by Art.31A.

court_reasoning.text: Does not defeat coparcenary rights except for ceiling claim; no transfer to Karta.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rights in retained area and compensation untouched.

court_reasoning.text: Art.15 challenge: not raised in writ, insufficient data; Punjab HC in Bhagat held no religious discrimination.

holdings.text: S.32-KK valid, protected by Art.31A as part of agrarian reform ceiling provisions.
Art.15 contention not examined due to procedural reasons and lack of data.

precedents_cited.relevance: Dismissed similar writ; no discrimination under Art.15 by S.32-KK.

precedents_cited.case_name: K. K. Kochuni v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.31A limited to agrarian reform; unlike that Act, this involves ceiling and surplus.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ranjit Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Liberal meaning to 'estate' in Art.31A; ceiling provisions part of agrarian reform.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pritam Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: S.32-FF valid under Art.31A; analogous to S.32-KK.

precedents_cited.case_name: I. C. Golak Nath v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Challenge to Art.31A no longer possible.

precedents_cited.case_name: Banarsi Das v. Wealth Tax Officer
precedents_cited.relevance: Hindu undivided family under Wealth Tax; not relevant to Art.15.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mammad Keyi v. Wealth Tax Officer

statutes_cited.name: Pepsu Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, XIII of 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Ceiling on land at 30 standard acres; acquisition of surplus; ignores post-1956 transfers; deems Hindu family land as Karta's for ceiling.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: S.32-KK protected by Art.31A from challenges under Arts.14,19,31; alleged violations.

outcome.summary: The Court held S.32-KK valid and protected by Art.31A as part of agrarian reform; contentions of unconstitutionality fail; Art.15 point not examined; appeal dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "where, immediately before the commencement of this Act, a landowner and his descendants constitute a Hindu undivided family, the land owned by such family shall, for the purposes of this Act, be deemed to be the land of that landowner"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of impugned S.32-KK defining the fiction.

key_quotes.text: "the fixing of ceiling on lands and provisions relating to it would form part of and constitute agrarian reform and, therefore, such provisions would have the protection of Art. 31-A."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on Art.31A protection for ceiling laws.

key_quotes.text: "section 32-KK deals with an estate within the meaning of Art. 31-A and is concerned with agrarian reform."
key_quotes.speaker: court
